Publishist

Setting Up A Custom Domain

No One Enjoys Setting Up DNS

When you first get started with Publishist, you'll have a brand new website at a domain like "example.publishist.com". If you own your own domain (for example, let's say you own "www.examplemag.com") and you want to point it at your Publishist website, you'll need to configure DNS.

To set up DNS, it helps to know a little bit about how it works. If you already know a good bit, feel free to skip to the next section.

A Wee Primer On DNS

Websites live on servers. A server is just a computer that has constant access to the internet, and is specially-configured to hand out web pages (that is, to "serve" web pages).

A website address like "publishist.com" is called a "domain name". Domain names are great for humans, but computers don't know how to use them. In order for your computer to talk to a server (some computer on the other side of the internet), it needs to know that server's IP address.

Think of an IP address as a computer's phone number. When you type in "example.publishist.com", your computer needs to figure out the phone number of that server. Then your computer asks that server for a web page, and the server creates the page and sends it back to you across the internet.

The way your computer figures out the phone number (IP address) of the server you want is the Domain Name System. There are a whole bunch of computers that just store phonebooks for the internet, mapping domain names like www.examplemag.com to IP addresses. These are called Domain Name Servers. When you enter a URL in your browser or click a link on a website, your computer asks these DNS servers to look up the IP address of the desired server, and then goes and fetches your web page from that server.

Configuring Your Custom Domain On Publishist

There are a few steps to get your Publishist website responding to your very own domain.

1. Register A Domain Name

You'll need to own a domain name in order to use it with Publishist. Publishist does not provide this service, but we recommend these registrars:

  • Hover
  • Name.com
  • Gandi
  • Namecheap

Please do NOT use GoDaddy. GoDaddy are a smarmy company that have poor customer service and want to censor the internet. If you've already registered a domain with them, consider switching.

2. Make Sure Your DNS Provider Is Fancy Enough

Your registrar from the previous step will probably let you configure your DNS settings. However, you don't need to use their DNS tools. It's likely that their DNS tools are pretty limited.

Any DNS service will let you complete step 3, however, to complete step 4 you'll need one with some advanced capabilities. You're welcome to not complete step 4, if you'd rather not bother and don't need the functionality.

The specific functionality you need is the ability to add a type of record sometimes called "HTTPRED", "ALIAS", or "Redirect". Here are some DNS services that allow this and what they call the record type:

  • DNSimple provides an ALIAS record
  • DNS Made Easy provides an HTTPRED record
  • Zerigo DNS provides a Redirect record

We recommend signing up with one of these services. Once you're signed up, you'll need to tell your registrar (from step 1) to use these new, alternate domain name servers, instead of their own. Your new DNS service will provide instructions on how to do this.

3. Map www.examplemag.com to example.publishist.com

OK! Now onto the easy part! Log in to your DNS provider and add new DNS record. You want to add a CNAME record pointing "www.examplemag.com" (or whatever your domain is) to example.publishist.com (or whatever URL you use to get to your Publishist site).

That's it! Once you've done this, it may take some time for your changes to make it onto all the other domain name servers across the internet. Sometimes it can take a couple days. But once your changes have propogated, you can visit your custom domain to get to your Publishist website!

4. Redirect examplemag.com to www.examplemag.com

People often don't type the "www." part of URLs. If you want people to be able to type in your web address without the "www", you'll need a fancy DNS service as described in step 2. Otherwise, if they forget to type the "www", they'll get an error or a totally different page.

If you have a DNS service that allows it, add an Alias, HTTPRED, or Redirect record pointing from examplemag.com (or whatever your custom domain is) to www.examplemag.com (your same custom domain, but with "www").

Once this change propogates across the internet, you should be able to type in just your root domain and get redirected to your "www" domain, which points to your Publishist site! Huzzah! All done.
